pullrequest.title: Don't shut down gazebo when removing a world -> gazebo7

content.raw:
I just found a deadlock ([full details here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/987051653d41c33a56e6a3f1080c1238)):

The `WorldRemoveTest.RemoveBlankWorld/2` test deadlocked.
The test called `physics::remove_worlds` at
[world_remove.cc:138](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a364ad2dd38cf7cc35/test/integration/world_remove.cc?at=worldless_7#world_remove.cc-138)
and that thread is waiting in `World::Fini` for the world run thread to join at
[World.cc:928](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a364ad2dd38cf7cc35/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=worldless_7#world_remove.cc-928).

The world run thread is currently in `World::Step`
[World.cc:642](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a364ad2dd38cf7cc35/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=worldless_7#world_remove.cc-642).
and is blocked waiting to get a recursive lock on `worldUpdateMutex`, but that mutex has already been deleted.

I'm not sure how it got into this state.
content.html:
I just found a deadlock (full details here):

The WorldRemoveTest.RemoveBlankWorld/2 test deadlocked. The test called physics::remove_worlds at world_remove.cc:138 and that thread is waiting in World::Fini for the world run thread to join at World.cc:928.

The world run thread is currently in World::Step World.cc:642. and is blocked waiting to get a recursive lock on worldUpdateMutex, but that mutex has already been deleted.

I'm not sure how it got into this state.

pullrequest.title: Don't shut down gazebo when removing a world -> gazebo7

content.raw:
I just saw a new flaky failure ([full details here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/0851378b520e92c9ea0759028abac5c0)):

The `WorldRemoveTest.RemoveBlankWorld/0` test called `physics::remove_worlds()` at
[world_remove.cc:138](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a364ad2dd38cf7cc3/test/integration/world_remove.cc?at=worldless_7#world_remove.cc-138)
but then seg-faulted as a consequence of calling `transport::getAdvertisedTopics()` at
[world_remove.cc:141](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a364ad2dd38cf7cc3/test/integration/world_remove.cc?at=worldless_7#world_remove.cc-141)
immediately after.
The seg-fault came from `ConnectionManager::GetAllPublishers` at
[ConnectionManager.cc:551](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a364ad2dd38cf7cc3/gazebo/transport/ConnectionManager.cc?at=worldless_7#world_remove.cc-551).
The `ConnectionManager` thread is currently in a timed wait at
[ConnectionManager.cc:316](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a364ad2dd38cf7cc3/gazebo/transport/ConnectionManager.cc?at=worldless_7#world_remove.cc-316).

I'm not sure what happened here.
content.html:
I just saw a new flaky failure (full details here):

The WorldRemoveTest.RemoveBlankWorld/0 test called physics::remove_worlds() at world_remove.cc:138 but then seg-faulted as a consequence of calling transport::getAdvertisedTopics() at world_remove.cc:141 immediately after. The seg-fault came from ConnectionManager::GetAllPublishers at ConnectionManager.cc:551. The ConnectionManager thread is currently in a timed wait at ConnectionManager.cc:316.

I'm not sure what happened here.

content.raw:
I'm using the following loop to run the stress test:

~~~
while test/integration/INTEGRATION_world_remove ; do date >> remove.txt; done
~~~

I also have `ulimit -c unlimited` so it will produce a core file in the current folder. I can also look at the number of lines in `remove.txt` to see how many times it ran successfully. You can also extract timing from the `date` command output, but I usually just count the lines in the file.
content.html:
I'm using the following loop to run the stress test:

while test/integration/INTEGRATION_world_remove ; do date >> remove.txt; done

I also have ulimit -c unlimited so it will produce a core file in the current folder. I can also look at the number of lines in remove.txt to see how many times it ran successfully. You can also extract timing from the date command output, but I usually just count the lines in the file.

content.raw:
Ok, I just found a flaky test failure in `WorldRemoveTest/WorldRemoveTest.RemoveWorldWithEntities/0` ([full details here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/d490e16fe186154181e519664fa6d4d0)).

A boost pointer assertion occurs while dereferencing a `gazebo::physics::SurfaceParams` pointer
in the function `gazebo::physics::ODEPhysics::Collide`
called from the `gazebo::physics::World::RunLoop` thread.

In the main thread, `gazebo::physics::remove_worlds` has been called and is deleting stuff.
We should probably wait for that `World::RunLoop` thread to stop before deleting everything.
content.html:
Ok, I just found a flaky test failure in WorldRemoveTest/WorldRemoveTest.RemoveWorldWithEntities/0 (full details here).

A boost pointer assertion occurs while dereferencing a gazebo::physics::SurfaceParams pointer in the function gazebo::physics::ODEPhysics::Collide called from the gazebo::physics::World::RunLoop thread.

In the main thread, gazebo::physics::remove_worlds has been called and is deleting stuff. We should probably wait for that World::RunLoop thread to stop before deleting everything.

pull_request.title: Don't shut down gazebo when removing a world -> gazebo7

pullrequest.title: Don't shut down gazebo when removing a world -> gazebo7

content.raw:
I think it looks ok to me. `SensorManager::worlds` gets modified in the following places:

* populated with `physics::get_world()` (the default world?) in `SensorManager::Update` if worlds is empty and worlds are running
* populated with `physics::get_world(_worldName)` in `SensorManager::CreateSensor` based on world name passed as function argument
* cleared during `SensorManager::Update` if `removeAllSensors` is true
* cleared during `SensorManager::Stop`
* cleared during `SensorManager::Fini`

I think it's reasonable to clear the worlds when removing sensors, since the worlds get added when sensors are created.
content.html:
I think it looks ok to me. SensorManager::worlds gets modified in the following places:

  • populated with physics::get_world() (the default world?) in SensorManager::Update if worlds is empty and worlds are running
  • populated with physics::get_world(_worldName) in SensorManager::CreateSensor based on world name passed as function argument
  • cleared during SensorManager::Update if removeAllSensors is true
  • cleared during SensorManager::Stop
  • cleared during SensorManager::Fini

I think it's reasonable to clear the worlds when removing sensors, since the worlds get added when sensors are created.

content.raw:
no, I meant to say that if we don't use this pointer during the loop, then we obviously aren't checking for changes in the timestep, so the `maxSensorUpdate` value may be out of date. Also, this is just a suspicion, I would have to write a test to confirm

so what would this mean:

Currently `maxSensorUpdate` is used to throttle the sensors, so if you have a sensor that wants to run at 10 kHz, but your physics steps are only 100 Hz when the simulation starts, it will throttle your sensor down to 100 Hz. If the time step later changes to `1 / 10kHz`, then sensors will still be running only at 100 Hz.

Conversely, if your sim starts at 10 kHz with sensors at 10 kHz, and then you reduce the physics time step to `1 / 100 Hz`, then your sensors will still try to run at 10 kHz.

It's definitely an edge case, but I think it's real?
content.html:
no, I meant to say that if we don't use this pointer during the loop, then we obviously aren't checking for changes in the timestep, so the maxSensorUpdate value may be out of date. Also, this is just a suspicion, I would have to write a test to confirm

so what would this mean:

Currently maxSensorUpdate is used to throttle the sensors, so if you have a sensor that wants to run at 10 kHz, but your physics steps are only 100 Hz when the simulation starts, it will throttle your sensor down to 100 Hz. If the time step later changes to 1 / 10kHz, then sensors will still be running only at 100 Hz.

Conversely, if your sim starts at 10 kHz with sensors at 10 kHz, and then you reduce the physics time step to 1 / 100 Hz, then your sensors will still try to run at 10 kHz.

It's definitely an edge case, but I think it's real?

content.raw:
Please let me know if I can give you more details about what's happening. 

Basically, when we were cleaning the state of the sensor manager (i.e. removing all sensors), the manager was still holding pointers to worlds. Since the sensor manager is a singleton and outlives worlds, it was preventing worlds from being properly destructed.
content.html:
Please let me know if I can give you more details about what's happening.

Basically, when we were cleaning the state of the sensor manager (i.e. removing all sensors), the manager was still holding pointers to worlds. Since the sensor manager is a singleton and outlives worlds, it was preventing worlds from being properly destructed.

pull_request.title: Don't shut down gazebo when removing a world -> gazebo7
